results.title: Sex
results.creator_credit: Martin Green, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
If every plant of a species was identical, they could all be susceptible to devastation caused by environmental change. This program explains pollination, different methods of seed dispersal, and a detailed examination of meiosis. This ensures that plants swap genetic information randomly, so that the next generation is genetically unique. The retention of old varieties of plants, such as types of wheat, demonstrates the need to store a variety of genetic material.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Green, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture

results.title: Growth and propagation
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
The concept of vegetative propagation is explained and how new plant cells are created in the growing points or meristems of plants. Discusses the importing of flower cuttings into Australia and the growing of potatoes. Using two case studies, the viewer is shown tissue culture techniques used to combat the plant disease Phytophthora, or “Jarrah dieback” and how genetic engineering is used to create a Blue Rose.

results.title: Friends and foes
results.creator_credit: Martin Green, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
There are major biotic factors which affect plant growth including the impact of pests and diseases and the competition with other plants for light and resources. Highlighted are some of the techniques developed to control these problems and the beneficial relationships which exist between plants and living organisms. A contemporary approach known as Integrated Pest Management looks at various methods used to control pests and disease while minimising environmental impact.

results.title: Soil
results.creator_credit: Robin Wischusen, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
A plant must absorb essential nutrients from the soil and how a plant utilises essential nutrients and trace elements through the fixed, exchangeable and soluble nutrient pools is shown. The Nitrogen cycle is also explained. Roots absorb soil nutrients and depending on whether there is an excess or defecit of nitrogen, the soil is either acidic or alkaline. Soil texture is explained and the modern day use of hydroponics.

results.title: Temperature
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Temperature influences a plant’s growth, and plants have developed strategies to cope with extremes in temperature. In commercial plant production, statistical techniques are used to determine mean temperatures for different areas. Combining temperature and time, gives the concept of ‘heat summation’ measured in ‘degree days’. Crop Modelling uses a computer to combine data on light intensity, temperature and the rate of photosynthesis to determine optimum growing conditions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivo Burum, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture

results.title: Water
results.creator_credit: Martin Green, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Water is a critical requirement for plant growth. This program examines different methods of watering commercial plants and how to measure water needs scientifically. Water moves from the roots throughout the plant, distributing nutrients and keeping the plant moist. This flow, called transpiration, is driven by diffusion, evaporation and capillary action. The plant uses osmosis to aid this process, and the importance of the Osmotic Gradient in how plants cope with drought, water-logging and salinity is discussed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Green, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture

results.title: Light
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Photosynthesis is the process by which a plant converts the energy from sunlight into sugars in specialised cells called chloroplasts. Respiration is the releasing of energy stored in sugars in the parts of the cells called mitochondria. The manipulation of light to simulate the natural habitat, shows how plant science can measure the relationship between light level and growth to determine optimum growing conditions.

results.title: Plants and people
results.creator_credit: Robin Wischusen, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
This program examines issues related to commercial farming considering the industry aspects of employment, economic value, the relationship between human dependence on plants and plant production, and the impact of technology. Examines the selective breeding used in the domestication of wheat and the use of genetic biology to provide a wider variety of product.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin Wischusen, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture
results.description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
This program examines issues related to commercial farming considering the industry aspects of employment, economic value, the relationship between human dependence on plants and plant production, and the impact of technology. Examines the selective breeding used in the domestication of wheat and the use of genetic biology to provide a wider variety of product.
description_for_label:

results.title: Mathematical eye
results.creator_credit: Colin Nobbs, Mike Cocker, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description: A series of 20 minute programs designed to help students understand mathematical concepts and relate them to the real world. The programs use computer graphics and animation to assist students in visualising problems and solutions.

results.title: Fun and games
results.creator_credit: Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematical eye”.
This program consists entirely of short mathematical puzzles that students answer using problem-solving techniques. It also presents games that can be played in the classroom and a basic introduction to algebra.
